In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is the solution in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int = 10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    lines = String[]
    current_line = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(current_line * " $word") > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = "$word"
        else
            current_line *= " $word"
        end
    end
    push!(lines, current_line)  # add the last line
    
    return join(lines, "\n")
end
```

This function splits the input string into words and iterates over each word. For each word, it checks if adding this word to the current line would exceed the maximum `text_width`. If so, it adds the current line to the list of lines and starts a new line with just the current word. Otherwise, it adds the word to the current line. After iterating over all words, it adds the last line to the list of lines. Finally, it joins all the lines into a single string separated by newline characters.

Example:
```julia
println(wrap_string("Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua.", 30))
```
This will output:
```
"Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,
consectetur adipiscing elit.
Sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt
ut labore et dolore magna aliqua."
```
